text: this is Martin factor with the New York
Times reporting from not woody the city
was made famous by these aerial images
of the tsunami that swept ashore
basically obliterated the town and the
farmland around it it was one of the
first images from Japan that really was
known internationally today the town
really looks like a war zone what was
left of a community of about 10,000
people was just a flattens plain of
shattered cords and crumpled and
discarded cars and clothing shoes golf
bags all sorts of things just scattered
everywhere rescue workers were going
through the debris trying to find
survivors and also the remains of the
victims what interesting thing is these
rural areas of Japan have very rapidly
aging populations and so it's it sounds
odd but it actually becomes a very big
issue because it affects not only
survival rates but also how do you
handle the survivors what sort of needs
that they have what sort of care do they
need and it's very different if you're a
75 year old survivor versus a 25 year
old or a young family which the things
that you might need the sort of medicine
sort of care is very different and so
Japan has to learn how to deal with
disasters when a great portion of your
population effective is elderly
you
